canonical_explanation.text: The atom, once thought to be indivisible, is composed of three fundamental subatomic particles: electrons (discovered by J.J. Thomson via cathode ray experiments, charge −1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ C, mass 9.109 × 10⁻³¹ kg), protons (discovered by Goldstein via anode rays, charge +1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ C, mass 1.673 × 10⁻²⁷ kg), and neutrons (discovered by Chadwick, no charge, mass 1.675 × 10⁻²⁷ kg). Thomson's plum pudding model proposed electrons embedded in a uniform sphere of positive charge. Rutherford's alpha-particle scattering experiment showed that the atom has a tiny, dense, positively charged nucleus with electrons revolving around it. However, Rutherford's model could not explain the stability of the atom or the line spectra of elements. Bohr's model introduced quantised orbits: electrons revolve in fixed circular orbits of definite energy (stationary states) around the nucleus. Energy is absorbed or emitted only when an electron transitions between orbits: ΔE = E₂ − E₁ = hν. The angular momentum of an electron is quantised: mvr = nh/2π. Bohr's model successfully explained hydrogen's line spectrum but failed for multi-electron atoms. The quantum mechanical model, developed by Schrödinger, treats the electron as a wave described by a wave function ψ. De Broglie proposed wave-particle duality: λ = h/mv. Heisenberg's uncertainty principle states that it is impossible to simultaneously determine the exact position and momentum of an electron: Δx · Δp ≥ h/4π. The Schrödinger wave equation gives solutions called orbitals, each characterised by quantum numbers. The principal quantum number (n) determines the energy level and size of the orbital. The azimuthal quantum number (l) determines the shape (l = 0 is s, l = 1 is p, l = 2 is d, l = 3 is f). The magnetic quantum number (mₗ) determines the orientation of the orbital. The spin quantum number (mₛ) specifies the spin direction (+½ or −½). Electronic configuration follows three rules: the Aufbau principle (fill orbitals in order of increasing energy, following the (n+l) rule), the Pauli exclusion principle (no two electrons can have all four quantum numbers identical; maximum 2 electrons per orbital with opposite spins), and Hund's rule of maximum multiplicity (electrons occupy degenerate orbitals singly with parallel spins before pairing).
rules: Electron: charge = −1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ C, mass = 9.109 × 10⁻³¹ kg; discovered by J.J. Thomson.
Proton: charge = +1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ C, mass = 1.673 × 10⁻²⁷ kg; discovered by Goldstein.
Neutron: no charge, mass ≈ 1.675 × 10⁻²⁷ kg; discovered by Chadwick.
Rutherford's experiment: most alpha particles pass through, a few are deflected, very few bounce back — proving a small dense nucleus.
Bohr's postulates: quantised orbits, angular momentum = nh/2π, energy emitted/absorbed during transitions ΔE = hν.
De Broglie wavelength: λ = h/mv (wave-particle duality).
Quantum numbers: n (shell), l (subshell/shape), mₗ (orientation), mₛ (spin).
Shapes: s orbital is spherical, p orbital is dumbbell-shaped, d orbital has cloverleaf shapes.
Aufbau principle: fill orbitals in order of increasing (n+l); if (n+l) is equal, lower n fills first.
Pauli exclusion: maximum 2 electrons per orbital with opposite spins.
Hund's rule: electrons singly occupy degenerate orbitals with parallel spins before pairing.

questions.question_text: Who discovered the electron using cathode ray discharge tube experiments?
questions.explanation_correct: J.J. Thomson discovered the electron in 1897 through cathode ray experiments. He determined the charge-to-mass ratio (e/m) of the electron and showed that cathode rays consist of negatively charged particles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rutherford discovered the nucleus via the gold foil experiment. Goldstein discovered canal rays (protons). Chadwick discovered the neutron.

questions.question_text: The neutron was discovered by:
questions.explanation_correct: James Chadwick discovered the neutron in 1932 by bombarding beryllium with alpha particles. The neutron is an electrically neutral subatomic particle with a mass slightly greater than that of a proton.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Thomson discovered the electron. Rutherford discovered the nucleus and the proton. Bohr proposed the quantised model of the atom.

questions.question_text: In Rutherford's alpha-particle scattering experiment, most alpha particles passed through the gold foil undeflected because:

options.text: The gold foil has many holes
Most of the atom is empty space

questions.explanation_correct: Most alpha particles passed through undeflected because the atom is mostly empty space. The nucleus occupies a very small fraction of the total volume of the atom (radius ratio ~ 10⁻⁵), so most particles do not encounter the nucleus.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Though alpha particles are heavy, that doesn't explain the lack of deflection. The gold foil is a continuous sheet, not full of holes. Alpha particles carry a +2 charge.

questions.question_text: In Thomson's plum pudding model of the atom:

options.text: Electrons revolve around the nucleus in fixed orbits
Electrons are embedded in a uniform sphere of positive charge
Electrons exist in probability clouds around the nucleus
Protons and neutrons form the nucleus

questions.explanation_correct: Thomson proposed that the atom is a uniform sphere of positive charge with electrons embedded in it like plums in a pudding. This model was later disproved by Rutherford's gold foil experiment.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fixed orbits are Bohr's model. Probability clouds are from the quantum mechanical model. The concept of a nucleus with protons and neutrons came from Rutherford and Chadwick.

questions.question_text: Which observation from Rutherford's experiment led to the conclusion that the nucleus is positively charged?

options.text: Most alpha particles passed through undeflected
Some alpha particles were deflected at small angles
A very few alpha particles bounced back nearly 180°
The gold foil did not break

questions.explanation_correct: A very few alpha particles (about 1 in 20,000) bounced back nearly 180°. Since alpha particles are positively charged and massive, only a concentrated positive charge (the nucleus) could repel them so strongly and cause them to reverse direction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Undeflected particles proved the atom is mostly empty. Small-angle deflections showed the positive charge is concentrated. The foil not breaking is irrelevant to the conclusion about nuclear charge.

questions.question_text: The charge-to-mass ratio (e/m) of an electron was first determined by:
questions.explanation_correct: J.J. Thomson determined the e/m ratio of the electron to be 1.758820 × 10¹¹ C/kg using cathode ray tube experiments with electric and magnetic fields.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Millikan determined the charge of the electron (oil drop experiment). Rutherford studied the nucleus. Bohr developed the quantised orbit model.

questions.question_text: The radius of the nucleus is of the order of 10⁻¹⁵ m while the radius of the atom is of the order of 10⁻¹⁰ m. The ratio of the volume of the nucleus to the volume of the atom is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: Volume is proportional to r³. Volume ratio = (r_nucleus/r_atom)³ = (10⁻¹⁵/10⁻¹⁰)³ = (10⁻⁵)³ = 10⁻¹⁵.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The ratio of radii is 10⁻⁵, but volume depends on the cube of the radius, so the volume ratio is (10⁻⁵)³ = 10⁻¹⁵, not 10⁻⁵, 10⁻¹⁰, or 10⁻²⁰.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly lists Millikan's contribution to atomic theory?

options.text: Determined the charge-to-mass ratio of the electron
Determined the charge on the electron using the oil drop experiment
Proposed the nuclear model of the atom

questions.explanation_correct: Robert Millikan determined the charge on the electron (e = 1.6022 × 10⁻¹⁹ C) through his famous oil drop experiment (1909). This, combined with Thomson's e/m ratio, allowed calculation of the electron's mass.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The e/m ratio was determined by Thomson. The proton was discovered by Goldstein/Rutherford. The nuclear model was proposed by Rutherford.

questions.question_text: An atom has 11 protons, 12 neutrons, and 11 electrons. Its mass number and atomic number are:
questions.explanation_correct: Mass number (A) = protons + neutrons = 11 + 12 = 23. Atomic number (Z) = number of protons = 11. This atom is sodium (Na).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Atomic number equals the number of protons (11), not neutrons or total particles. Mass number is the sum of protons and neutrons (23), not protons alone or all three particles.

questions.question_text: According to Bohr's model, the angular momentum of an electron in a stationary orbit is:
questions.explanation_correct: Bohr postulated that the angular momentum of an electron in a permitted orbit is quantised and equals an integral multiple of h/2π, i.e., mvr = nh/2π, where n = 1, 2, 3, ...
questions.explanation_incorrect: Energy is proportional to −1/n², and radius is proportional to n², but angular momentum is directly proportional to n and equals nh/2π. It is never zero for any allowed orbit.

questions.question_text: The energy of the electron in the nth orbit of hydrogen atom according to Bohr's model is given by:
questions.explanation_correct: In Bohr's model, the energy of an electron in the nth orbit of hydrogen is Eₙ = −13.6/n² eV. The negative sign indicates the electron is bound to the nucleus.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The energy depends on 1/n², not 1/n or n². The energy is always negative for bound states (positive would mean the electron is free).

questions.question_text: The hydrogen spectrum series that falls in the visible region is:
questions.explanation_correct: The Balmer series (transitions to n = 2) falls in the visible region of the electromagnetic spectrum. The wavelengths range from about 400 nm (violet) to 656 nm (red).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Lyman series (transitions to n = 1) falls in the ultraviolet region. The Paschen (to n = 3), Brackett (to n = 4), and Pfund (to n = 5) series fall in the infrared region.

questions.question_text: The radius of the first Bohr orbit of hydrogen is 0.529 A. The radius of the third orbit is:
questions.explanation_correct: In Bohr's model, the radius of the nth orbit rₙ = n² × r₁. For n = 3: r₃ = 9 × 0.529 = 4.761 A.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 1.587 A would be 3 × r₁ (linear proportionality, incorrect). 2.645 A would be 5 × r₁. 0.176 A would be r₁/3. The radius scales as n².

questions.question_text: The number of spectral lines produced when an electron in hydrogen falls from the 4th orbit to the ground state is:
questions.explanation_correct: The number of spectral lines from level n to the ground state = n(n−1)/2 = 4(3)/2 = 6. The possible transitions are: 4→3, 4→2, 4→1, 3→2, 3→1, 2→1.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 3 lines would be for n = 3. 4 is just n. 10 would be for n = 5. The formula n(n−1)/2 gives the total number of spectral lines.

questions.question_text: In the Bohr model of hydrogen, the ratio of the velocities of the electron in the first and third orbits (v₁/v₃) is:
questions.explanation_correct: In Bohr's model, the velocity of the electron in the nth orbit vₙ ∝ 1/n. Therefore, v₁/v₃ = 3/1 = 3 : 1.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Velocity is inversely proportional to n (not n² or directly proportional). So v₁ : v₃ = (1/1) : (1/3) = 3 : 1.

questions.question_text: The ionisation energy of hydrogen atom from the ground state is 13.6 eV. The energy required to excite the electron from n = 1 to n = 3 is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: 10.2 eV is the energy for the n = 1 to n = 2 transition. 1.51 eV is the energy of the third orbit (not the transition energy). 3.4 eV is the energy of the second orbit.

questions.question_text: The wavelength of the first line in the Balmer series of hydrogen spectrum is 656 nm. The wavelength of the second Balmer line is approximately:
questions.explanation_incorrect: 434 nm is the third Balmer line (n=5→2). 410 nm is the fourth Balmer line (n=6→2). 364 nm is close to the series limit.

questions.question_text: A major limitation of Bohr's model is that it:

options.text: Cannot explain the spectrum of hydrogen
Does not account for the wave nature of the electron
Violates the law of conservation of energy
Does not use Planck's quantum theory

questions.explanation_correct: Bohr's model treats the electron as a particle moving in fixed circular orbits. It does not account for the wave nature of the electron (de Broglie's hypothesis) and cannot explain spectra of multi-electron atoms, the Zeeman effect, or the Stark effect.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bohr's model successfully explains the hydrogen spectrum. It does not violate conservation of energy. It does incorporate Planck's quantum theory (E = hν for transitions).

questions.question_text: The de Broglie wavelength of a particle is given by:
questions.explanation_correct: De Broglie proposed that matter has wave-like properties, and the wavelength is given by λ = h/mv = h/p, where h is Planck's constant, m is mass, and v is velocity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: λ = mv/h, λ = h × mv, and λ = m/hv are all incorrect forms. The correct relationship is λ = h/(mv), showing that wavelength is inversely proportional to momentum.

questions.question_text: Heisenberg's uncertainty principle states that:

options.text: The energy of an electron can never be determined
It is impossible to simultaneously determine the exact position and momentum of an electron
Electrons can exist anywhere in the atom
The electron has only particle nature

questions.explanation_correct: Heisenberg's uncertainty principle states that it is impossible to simultaneously determine the exact position and exact momentum of a microscopic particle like an electron. Mathematically: Δx · Δp ≥ h/4π.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Energy can be determined (just not simultaneously with time, to exact precision). Electrons exist in specific orbitals with defined probability distributions. The electron exhibits wave-particle duality, not just particle nature.

questions.question_text: In the quantum mechanical model, an orbital represents:

options.text: A definite circular path of the electron
The three-dimensional region where the probability of finding an electron is maximum
The energy of the electron only

questions.explanation_correct: In the quantum mechanical model, an orbital is a three-dimensional region around the nucleus where there is a high probability (typically 90-95%) of finding an electron. It is described by the wave function ψ, and |ψ|² gives the probability density.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A definite circular path is from Bohr's model, not quantum mechanics. An orbital provides spatial probability information, not just energy or speed.

questions.question_text: The de Broglie wavelength of a ball of mass 0.1 kg moving at 10 m/s is: (h = 6.626 × 10⁻³⁴ J·s)
questions.explanation_correct: λ = h/mv = (6.626 × 10⁻³⁴)/(0.1 × 10) = (6.626 × 10⁻³⁴)/1 = 6.626 × 10⁻³⁴ m. This extremely small wavelength shows why wave properties of macroscopic objects are unobservable.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The calculation is straightforward: h/(mv) = 6.626 × 10⁻³⁴/(0.1 × 10) = 6.626 × 10⁻³⁴ m. The other options result from errors in the power of 10.

questions.question_text: If the uncertainty in position of an electron is 10⁻¹⁰ m, the minimum uncertainty in its momentum is: (h = 6.626 × 10⁻³⁴ J·s)
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using Heisenberg's relation Δx·Δp ≥ h/4π: Δp = 6.626 × 10⁻³⁴/(4π × 10⁻¹⁰) ≈ 5.27 × 10⁻²⁵ kg·m/s. The other options have incorrect powers of 10.

questions.question_text: The wave function ψ of an electron in an atom has:

options.text: No physical significance; only |ψ|² has significance
Direct physical meaning as the probability of finding the electron
The same value at all points in space

questions.explanation_correct: The wave function ψ itself has no direct physical significance. However, |ψ|² (the square of the wave function) gives the probability density of finding the electron at a given point in space. This is Born's interpretation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: ψ does not directly give probability; |ψ|² does. ψ is part of quantum mechanics, not Bohr's model. ψ varies from point to point in space.

questions.question_text: The principal quantum number (n) determines:

options.text: The size and energy of the orbital

questions.explanation_correct: The principal quantum number (n) determines the size and energy of the orbital. As n increases, the orbital becomes larger and the electron has higher energy (less negative for hydrogen).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The shape is determined by the azimuthal quantum number (l). The orientation is determined by the magnetic quantum number (mₗ). The spin is determined by the spin quantum number (mₛ).

questions.question_text: The azimuthal quantum number l = 2 corresponds to which subshell?
questions.explanation_correct: The azimuthal quantum number l determines the subshell: l = 0 (s), l = 1 (p), l = 2 (d), l = 3 (f). Therefore, l = 2 corresponds to the d subshell.
questions.explanation_incorrect: l = 0 is the s subshell, l = 1 is the p subshell, l = 3 is the f subshell. The d subshell has l = 2.

questions.question_text: The shape of a p orbital is:
questions.explanation_correct: A p orbital has a dumbbell shape (two lobes on either side of the nucleus with a nodal plane in between). There are three p orbitals (pₓ, pᵧ, p_z) oriented along the three coordinate axes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Spherical is the shape of s orbitals. Cloverleaf shapes are characteristic of most d orbitals. Conical does not describe any standard atomic orbital.

questions.question_text: For the 3d subshell, the possible values of the magnetic quantum number mₗ are:
questions.explanation_correct: For the d subshell, l = 2. The magnetic quantum number mₗ ranges from −l to +l, so mₗ = −2, −1, 0, +1, +2. This gives 5 orbitals in the d subshell.
questions.explanation_incorrect: mₗ = −1, 0, +1 applies to the p subshell (l = 1). mₗ = −3 to +3 applies to the f subshell (l = 3). mₗ ranges from −l to +l, including negative values.

questions.question_text: The maximum number of electrons in a shell with principal quantum number n = 3 is:
questions.explanation_correct: The maximum number of electrons in a shell = 2n². For n = 3: 2(3²) = 2(9) = 18. The third shell has 3s (2), 3p (6), and 3d (10) subshells, totalling 18 electrons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 8 is the maximum for n = 2. 32 is the maximum for n = 4. 10 is the capacity of just the d subshell.

questions.question_text: The number of radial nodes in a 3s orbital is:
questions.explanation_correct: Number of radial (spherical) nodes = n − l − 1. For 3s: n = 3, l = 0. Radial nodes = 3 − 0 − 1 = 2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The 1s orbital has 0 nodes, the 2s has 1 node. For 3s, using n − l − 1 = 3 − 0 − 1 = 2 radial nodes.

questions.question_text: Which set of quantum numbers is NOT allowed?
questions.explanation_correct: For n = 2, the allowed values of l are 0 and 1 only (l ranges from 0 to n−1). l = 2 is not allowed for n = 2, making this set invalid.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Set A (2p orbital) is valid. Set B (3d orbital) is valid. Set D (4f orbital) is valid. Only set C violates the rule l < n.

questions.question_text: The total number of orbitals in the fourth shell (n = 4) is:
questions.explanation_correct: Total orbitals in a shell = n². For n = 4: 4² = 16 orbitals. These are: 4s (1) + 4p (3) + 4d (5) + 4f (7) = 16.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 9 is n² for n = 3. 25 is for n = 5. 32 is the maximum number of electrons (2n²), not orbitals.

questions.question_text: According to the Aufbau principle, electrons fill orbitals in order of:
questions.explanation_correct: The Aufbau principle states that electrons fill orbitals in order of increasing energy. The order follows the (n+l) rule: the orbital with the lower (n+l) value fills first; if two orbitals have the same (n+l), the one with lower n fills first.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Electrons fill from lowest to highest energy, not decreasing energy. The filling order depends on (n+l), not just n or l alone.

questions.question_text: The Pauli exclusion principle states that:

options.text: No two electrons in an atom can have the same set of four quantum numbers
Electrons always pair up in the same orbital
Electrons in the same subshell must have parallel spins
An orbital can hold a maximum of 4 electrons

questions.explanation_correct: The Pauli exclusion principle states that no two electrons in an atom can have all four quantum numbers identical. This means each orbital can hold a maximum of 2 electrons with opposite spins (mₛ = +½ and −½).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Electrons don't always pair up; they follow Hund's rule and singly fill degenerate orbitals first. Electrons in the same subshell singly occupy orbitals with parallel spins (Hund's rule) before pairing. An orbital holds at most 2 electrons, not 4.

questions.question_text: According to Hund's rule, electrons in the same subshell first occupy orbitals:
questions.explanation_correct: Hund's rule of maximum multiplicity states that electrons occupy degenerate orbitals (orbitals of equal energy within a subshell) singly with parallel spins before any pairing occurs. This minimises electron-electron repulsion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pairing occurs only after all degenerate orbitals are singly occupied. When occupying singly, spins are parallel (all +½ or all −½), not antiparallel. Pairs cannot have parallel spins (violates Pauli principle).

questions.question_text: The electronic configuration of nitrogen (Z = 7) is:
questions.explanation_correct: Nitrogen has 7 electrons. Following the Aufbau principle: 1s² (2), 2s² (4), 2p³ (7). The three 2p electrons occupy the three p orbitals singly with parallel spins (Hund's rule).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other configurations either violate the Aufbau principle (filling 3s before 2p is full is wrong for 7 electrons) or do not follow the correct filling order.

questions.question_text: The electronic configuration of chromium (Z = 24) is:
questions.explanation_correct: Chromium is an exception to the Aufbau principle. Instead of [Ar] 3d⁴ 4s², its actual configuration is [Ar] 3d⁵ 4s¹ because a half-filled d subshell (d⁵) provides extra stability due to symmetrical distribution and exchange energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: [Ar] 3d⁴ 4s² would be the expected configuration but is not the actual one. [Ar] 3d³ 4s² 4p¹ incorrectly places an electron in 4p. [Ar] 3d⁶ accounts for only 24 electrons but leaves the 4s orbital empty, which is not the ground state.

questions.question_text: The electronic configuration of copper (Z = 29) is:
questions.explanation_correct: Copper is an exception to the Aufbau principle. Its actual configuration is [Ar] 3d¹⁰ 4s¹ (not [Ar] 3d⁹ 4s²) because a completely filled d subshell (d¹⁰) provides extra stability.
questions.explanation_incorrect: [Ar] 3d⁹ 4s² would be the expected configuration but is not observed. [Ar] 3d⁸ 4s² 4p¹ has an electron incorrectly placed in 4p. [Ar] 3d¹⁰ 4s² would have 30 electrons (that's zinc).

questions.question_text: Which of the following orbitals has the lowest energy according to the (n+l) rule?
questions.explanation_correct: According to the (n+l) rule, the orbital with the lowest (n+l) value has the lowest energy. 4s has n+l = 4+0 = 4, which is less than 5 for all other listed orbitals. So 4s fills first.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 3d, 4p, and 5s all have n+l = 5, which is higher than 4s (n+l = 4). Among those three with equal n+l, the one with lower n (3d) fills first, but all fill after 4s.

questions.question_text: An element has the electronic configuration [Ar] 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p³. Its atomic number is:
questions.explanation_correct: [Ar] represents 18 electrons. Adding 3d¹⁰ (10) + 4s² (2) + 4p³ (3) = 15 more electrons. Total = 18 + 15 = 33. This is arsenic (As).
questions.explanation_incorrect: 35 would be [Ar] 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁵ (Br). 31 would be [Ar] 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p¹ (Ga). 34 would be [Ar] 3d¹⁰ 4s² 4p⁴ (Se).

questions.question_text: The number of unpaired electrons in the ground state of Fe (Z = 26) is:
questions.explanation_correct: Fe: [Ar] 3d⁶ 4s². In the 3d subshell with 6 electrons and 5 orbitals: by Hund's rule, 5 electrons fill singly (all with parallel spins), then the 6th pairs up in one orbital. This gives 4 unpaired electrons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: With 6 electrons in 5 d orbitals, one orbital must be doubly occupied, leaving 4 unpaired electrons. 2 would be for d² or d⁸. 3 would be for d³ or d⁷. 5 would be for d⁵.

questions.question_text: Which of the following pairs are isoelectronic?
questions.explanation_correct: Na⁺ has 11 − 1 = 10 electrons. Mg²⁺ has 12 − 2 = 10 electrons. Both have 10 electrons, so they are isoelectronic (also isoelectronic with Ne, F⁻, O²⁻, and N³⁻).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Na⁺ (10e) and K⁺ (18e) are not isoelectronic. Cl⁻ (18e) and Br⁻ (36e) are not isoelectronic. Fe²⁺ (24e) and Fe³⁺ (23e) are not isoelectronic.

questions.question_text: An electron and a proton have the same kinetic energy. Which has a longer de Broglie wavelength?
questions.explanation_correct: λ = h/p = h/√(2mKE). For the same kinetic energy, λ ∝ 1/√m. Since the electron has a much smaller mass than the proton, it has a longer de Broglie wavelength.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since λ = h/√(2mKE), the lighter particle (electron) has a longer wavelength. The proton, being about 1836 times heavier, has a shorter wavelength.

questions.question_text: The number of angular nodes in a 4d orbital is:
questions.explanation_correct: The number of angular nodes = l. For a d orbital, l = 2. Therefore, a 4d orbital has 2 angular nodes. (Total nodes = n − 1 = 3; radial nodes = n − l − 1 = 4 − 2 − 1 = 1; angular nodes = 2.)
questions.explanation_incorrect: Angular nodes depend only on l, not n. For d orbitals (l = 2), there are always 2 angular nodes regardless of the principal quantum number.

questions.question_text: In the Lyman series, the spectral line with the longest wavelength corresponds to the transition:
questions.explanation_correct: The longest wavelength (lowest energy) in any spectral series corresponds to the smallest energy transition — from the nearest higher orbit. For the Lyman series (transitions to n = 1), this is n = 2 → n = 1.
questions.explanation_incorrect: n = ∞ → 1 gives the shortest wavelength (series limit). n = 3 → 1 and n = 4 → 1 have shorter wavelengths than n = 2 → 1 because they involve larger energy differences.

questions.question_text: Isotopes are atoms of the same element that have:

options.text: Different atomic numbers but same mass numbers
Same atomic numbers but different mass numbers
Same mass numbers but different atomic numbers
Different atomic numbers and different mass numbers

questions.explanation_correct: Isotopes are atoms of the same element (same atomic number Z) that have different mass numbers (A) due to different numbers of neutrons. For example, ¹H, ²H (deuterium), and ³H (tritium) are isotopes of hydrogen.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Same Z but different A defines isotopes. Same A but different Z defines isobars. Different Z and different A are just different elements.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about the quantum mechanical model is incorrect?

options.text: The energy of electrons is quantised
The exact path of an electron around the nucleus is well defined
The probability of finding an electron is described by |ψ|²

questions.explanation_correct: In the quantum mechanical model, the exact path (trajectory) of an electron is not well defined due to the Heisenberg uncertainty principle. Only the probability of finding the electron in a given region is known, described by |ψ|².
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other three statements are correct features of the quantum mechanical model: energy is quantised, |ψ|² gives probability density, and electrons exhibit wave-particle duality.

questions.question_text: Which of the following orbitals has the highest energy in a multi-electron atom?
questions.explanation_correct: In a multi-electron atom, orbitals within the same shell have different energies due to shielding: 3s < 3p < 3d. Also, 4s fills before 3d (lower n+l), but 3d has higher energy than 4s in the neutral atom during filling. However, 3d (n+l=5) is higher in energy than 4s (n+l=4) in the filling order, making 3d the highest energy among these options.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In a multi-electron atom, energy depends on both n and l. 3s < 3p < 4s < 3d in the Aufbau filling order, so 3d has the highest energy among the given options.

questions.question_text: The electronic configuration of the oxide ion O²⁻ (Z of O = 8) is:
questions.explanation_correct: O²⁻ has 8 + 2 = 10 electrons (same as neon). Its electronic configuration is 1s² 2s² 2p⁶.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 1s² 2s² 2p⁴ is the configuration of neutral oxygen (8 electrons). 1s² 2s² 2p⁵ is fluorine (9 electrons). 1s² 2s² 2p² is carbon (6 electrons).

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the correct order of filling of orbitals according to the Aufbau principle?
questions.explanation_correct: Following the (n+l) rule: 1s (1), 2s (2), 2p (3), 3s (3), 3p (4), 4s (4), 3d (5). When n+l is the same (e.g., 3p and 4s both have n+l=4), the one with lower n fills first. So the order is 1s, 2s, 2p, 3s, 3p, 4s, 3d.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A fills 3d before 4s, which is incorrect. Options C and D have 3s before 2p or 4s before 3p, which violate the (n+l) rule.
